      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-137213-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>This article reviews an incident where a threat actor unsuccessfully tried bypassing Cortex XDR. By digging further into the incident, the process instead provided us with insight into the threat actor's operations.</p>
<p>In a recent investigation involving an extortion attempt, we discovered a threat actor had purchased access to the client network via Atera RMM from an initial access broker. We discovered the threat actor used rogue systems to install the Cortex XDR agent onto a virtual system. They did this to test a new antivirus/endpoint detection and response (AV/EDR) bypass tool leveraging the <a href="https://blogs.vmware.com/security/2023/04/bring-your-own-backdoor-how-vulnerable-drivers-let-hackers-in.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">bring your own vulnerable driver (BYOVD) technique</a>.</p>
<p>Connectivity between this virtual system and the client's network inadvertently gave Unit 42 investigators a certain level of access to the rogue systems. This provided visibility into various tools and files held by the threat actor. While the threat actor intended to find a way to bypass Cortex, in actuality this activity helped Unit 42 protect other organizations by providing unique visibility into the threat actor's tooling, targeting and persona.</p>
<p>In this report, we provide an overview of the attack that occurred, details about the AV/EDR bypass tool, and its sale on cybercrime forums. Most importantly, we offer a walkthrough for how Unit 42 researchers managed to unmask one of the threat actors involved. We’ll give a peek into all the discoveries related to the identification of the threat actor.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsiam" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration/url-filtering-basics/how-url-filtering-works" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security/administration/about-dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%; height: 24px;">
<thead>
<tr style="height: 24px;">
<td style="width: 35%; height: 24px;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%; height: 24px;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/extortion/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Extortion</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/data-exfiltration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Data Exfiltration</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-137213-_gqi6y5lx0gca"></a>Overview</h2>
<p>Unit 42 was called to assist with an extortion incident. Through the investigation process, we encountered two endpoints involved in the attack that were unknown to the client environment.</p>
<p>As a means to test an AV/EDR bypass tool, these endpoints had older versions of Cortex XDR agents installed. Unbeknownst to the threat actor, we were able to access these rogue endpoints.</p>
<p>We also discovered a series of toolkits and other files belonging to the threat actor on the system, which included the bypass tool. We successfully traced and identified posts related to the sale of this specific tool on cybercrime forums like XSS and Exploit.</p>
<p>Using files obtained from the rogue endpoints and subsequent investigation, we discovered the true identity of one of the threat actors involved in the incident. We also found additional information about the individual's personal and professional background.</p>
<p>Figure 1 presents a high-level chain of events in the attack investigated by Unit 42.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137217" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137217" style="width: 2048px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137217 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-353688-137213-1.png" alt="Flowchart titled 'High Level Chain of Events' depicting various cybersecurity threats and responses. Includes icons and text describing initial access via Atera, external threats from actors, rogue machines connected to a network, lateral movement within a network, and internal discovery along with credential access and defense evasion. The last step is exfiltration. Each step is interconnected with arrows showing the flow of events." width="2048" height="1542" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-353688-137213-1.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-353688-137213-1-584x440.png 584w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-353688-137213-1-930x700.png 930w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-353688-137213-1-768x578.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-353688-137213-1-1536x1157.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137217" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. High-level chain of events for this attack.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-137213-_7xuhqwyga4uz"></a>AV/EDR Bypass Tool</h2>
<p>The particular tool, named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">disabler.exe</span>, appears to use the publicly available source code from <a href="https://github.com/wavestone-cdt/EDRSandblast" target="_blank" rel="noopener">EDRSandBlast</a> with small modifications and removal of the CLI features. This is evidenced by similarity in content in EDRSandBlast source code files shown in Figure 2 and referenced in the binary as shown in Figure 3. We have noted some of the similarities in red in both figures.</p>
<p>The tool's primary function is to target and remove EDR hooks in user-mode libraries and kernel-mode callbacks. It includes a companion file, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">wnbios.sys</span> or <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WN_64.sys</span>, which is a vulnerable driver that the tool attempts to load and gain access to.</p>
<h3></h3>
<figure id="attachment_137219" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137219" style="width: 2048px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137219 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-357864-137213-2.png" alt="Screenshot of a GitHub page displaying multiple code snippets in a red, green, and white color scheme, with annotations and arrows highlighting specific lines. The code relates to utility functions, offsite extractions, and service operations." width="2048" height="1850" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-357864-137213-2.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-357864-137213-2-487x440.png 487w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-357864-137213-2-775x700.png 775w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-357864-137213-2-768x694.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-357864-137213-2-1536x1388.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137219" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Snippet of some of the strings printed by EDRSandBlast.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_137254" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137254" style="width: 2268px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137254 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TA-phone-home-Fig-3-539x440.jpg" alt="Screenshot of a computer screen displaying a list of function names and their corresponding addresses in a programming environment. There are arrows and text annotations in red pointing to specific lines in the code." width="2268" height="1850" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TA-phone-home-Fig-3-539x440.jpg 539w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TA-phone-home-Fig-3-858x700.jpg 858w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TA-phone-home-Fig-3-768x626.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TA-phone-home-Fig-3-1536x1253.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TA-phone-home-Fig-3.jpg 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 2268px) 100vw, 2268px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137254" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Same strings seen in disabler.exe static library.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Based on certain files and folders in one of the rogue endpoints, we searched cybercrime forums such as XSS and Exploit to identify the likely seller of this bypass tool.</p>
<h3></h3>
<h3><a id="post-137213-_bu532ehco6u3"></a>Identifying the Seller of the Bypass Tool</h3>
<p>The rogue system had a hostname of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DESKTOP-J8AOTJS</span> and contained several directories with interesting names under the file path <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Z:\freelance</span>. This led us to the hypothesis that these were names or monikers of various other affiliates as shown below in Figure 4.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137269" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137269" style="width: 200px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137269 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TAPhone_Fig4-200x700.png" alt="A spreadsheet displaying a list of usernames. The format includes a column for folder names shown in a grid layout." width="200" height="700" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TAPhone_Fig4-200x700.png 200w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TAPhone_Fig4-126x440.png 126w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TAPhone_Fig4-438x1536.png 438w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/TAPhone_Fig4.png 478w" sizes="(max-width: 200px) 100vw, 200px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137269" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. List of folders in Z:\freelance on the rogue system.</figcaption></figure>
<p>With that in mind, we searched cybercrime forums for usernames matching any of the directory names under <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Z:\freelance</span>. While some of them were either too noisy or didn’t return any result at all, the rest did return some interesting hits. The matching names consistently posted either in the Russian language, or they posted in Russian-based cybercrime forums, the most common being XSS and Exploit.</p>
<p>The username that piqued our interest the most was <em>Marti71</em>. This username posted in multiple places looking for tools to bypass AV/EDR. Figure 5 shows one such example, with the post translated to English as follows:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Greetings, everyone!</span></p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Does anyone have an out-of-the-box solution to kill antivirus software? I'm ready to purchase several solutions with regular support/subscription.</span></p>
<figure id="attachment_137223" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137223" style="width: 2048px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137223 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-373594-137213-5.png" alt="Screenshot of an online forum thread titled 'AV KILLER' dated December 25, 2024. The thread includes comments from a user named 'Marti71' discussing technical topics related to antivirus software. The interface features options for replying and reporting comments. The script used in the posts is Cyrillic. " width="2048" height="683" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-373594-137213-5.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-373594-137213-5-786x262.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-373594-137213-5-1920x640.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-373594-137213-5-768x256.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-373594-137213-5-1536x512.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137223" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Marti71 inquiring about antivirus killing software.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The final post on this thread was from a user account named <em>KernelMode, </em>suggesting an AV/EDR bypass tool.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137225" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137225" style="width: 1737px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137225 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-376833-137213-6.png" alt="Image displaying two user comments from a forum. The first comment is by a user named HostBurn with a profile icon of a woman, commenting in Russian, dated January 25, 2024. The second comment is by KernelMode, also dated January 25, 2024, featuring a green &quot;C++&quot; profile icon." width="1737" height="476" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-376833-137213-6.png 1737w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-376833-137213-6-786x215.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-376833-137213-6-768x210.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-376833-137213-6-1536x421.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1737px) 100vw, 1737px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137225" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. User KernelMode suggesting an AV/EDR bypass tool.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Pivoting to the link in <em>KernelMode</em>'s post in Figure 6, we found a thread that <em>KernelMode</em> initiated to sell subscriptions to an AV/EDR bypass tool as Figure 7 shows. However, the post contains nothing that would confirm that the person or people behind <em>KernelMode</em> are the developers of this bypass tool.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137227" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137227" style="width: 2048px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137227 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-379983-137213-7.png" alt="Screenshot of an online forum post by KernelMode dated January 16, 2024. The post is in Cyrillic script and has beem translated into English. " width="2048" height="869" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-379983-137213-7.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-379983-137213-7-786x334.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-379983-137213-7-1650x700.png 1650w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-379983-137213-7-768x326.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-379983-137213-7-1536x652.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137227" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. KernelMode posting about the sale of an AV/EDR bypass tool.</figcaption></figure>
<p><em>Marti71 </em>also posted on this thread as shown in Figure 8, which seems to indicate a positive experience with the tool.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137229" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137229" style="width: 2048px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137229 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-383667-137213-8.png" alt="Screenshot of online forum post by Marti71 in Cyrillic dated April 24, 2024. " width="2048" height="543" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-383667-137213-8.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-383667-137213-8-786x208.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-383667-137213-8-1920x509.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-383667-137213-8-768x204.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-383667-137213-8-1536x407.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137229" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Marti71’s comment on the bypass tool.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This Russian language post translates to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">In general, it will go, finishing some moments, trying to speed up. Bitdef/sentic fly off quickly.</span></p>
<p>Going back to <em>KernelMode</em>’s post, the actor mentions at the end that they will provide a video demonstration. We were able to procure an archive of multiple recordings demonstrating the tool. Each recording shows a particular AV/EDR agent installed at that point that included the execution of the bypassing tool followed by a successful execution of Mimikatz. The intent of the demonstration is to illustrate that the AV/EDR agent has been bypassed to an extent.</p>
<p>We found files for such tool demonstration recordings on the rogue system as well. Comparing the recordings on the rogue system with recordings from <em>KernelMode</em> revealed they were exactly the same. Figure 9 shows a screenshot from one of the recordings.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137231" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137231" style="width: 894px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137231 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-386456-137213-9.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer screen with two open command prompt windows, displaying codes and commands related to software installation and system checks." width="894" height="553" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-386456-137213-9.png 894w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-386456-137213-9-711x440.png 711w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-386456-137213-9-768x475.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 894px) 100vw, 894px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137231" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Snippet of the AV/EDR bypass tool demonstration video from KernelMode also on the rogue system.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-137213-_m5ixlg3m4x8y"></a>Peek into the Rogue System</h2>
<h3><a id="post-137213-_ury9ld77j13b"></a><strong>Overview of Tools and Files</strong></h3>
<p>We retrieved a portion of files in the shared <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Z:\</span> drive of the rogue system <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DESKTOP-J8AOTJS</span>. Figure 10 shows some of the files captured.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137233" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137233" style="width: 2048px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137233 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-389503-137213-10.png" alt="Screenshot of a file explorer window displaying a list of various types of files including zip, exe, jpg, and more. File names are visible, with details about file size and the columns of 'Creation Date', 'Last Modified', and 'Size' shown." width="2048" height="1906" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-389503-137213-10.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-389503-137213-10-473x440.png 473w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-389503-137213-10-752x700.png 752w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-389503-137213-10-768x715.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-389503-137213-10-1536x1430.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137233" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Files and folders on the root path.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Highlights of the captured material include:</p>
<ul>
<li>An encrypted archive file <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ContiTraining.rar</span> was present in the system</li>
<li>The extracted archive contains a torrent file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ContiTraining.torrent</span> that was created on Aug. 14, 2021</li>
<li>This torrent file would reach out to the following servers to download the <a href="https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/angry-conti-ransomware-affiliate-leaks-gangs-attack-playbook/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Conti playbook that was publicly leaked in 2021</a>:
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">udp[://]tracker.coppersurfer[.]tk:6969</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">udp[://]9.rarbg[.]to:2920</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">udp[://]tracker.opentrackr[.]org:1337</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">udp[://]tracker.leechers-paradise[.]org:6969</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">udp[://]exodus.desync[.]com:6969</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Files specified by <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ContiTraining.torrent</span> to be downloaded:
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Кряк 2019.rar</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Метасплоит US.rar</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Метасплоит RU.zip</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Network Pentesting.rar</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Cobalt Strike.rar</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Powershell for Pentesters+.rar</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Windows Red Team Lab+.rar</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WMI Attacks and Defense +.rar</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Abusing SQL Server Trusts in a Windows Domain+.rar</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Attacking and Defending Active Directory+.rar</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GCB.zip</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GeekBrayns Реверс-инжиниринг.rar</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>A folder with files containing personally identifiable information (PII) and other confidential information on one individual such as:
<ul>
<li>Their name</li>
<li>Device details</li>
<li>Phone number</li>
<li>An account number</li>
<li>A two-factor authentication-based key</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Multiple copies of the AV/EDR bypass tool along with video demonstrations, as explained above</li>
<li>Various builds of the Mimikatz tool, probably for the purposes of testing out the AV/EDR bypass tool</li>
<li>Various tools that were either sourced from GitHub or underground forums, with functionalities such as:
<ul>
<li>Shellcode generation and execution</li>
<li>Kernel driver utilities</li>
<li>Code obfuscation</li>
<li>Protection bypass</li>
<li>Anti-cheat bypass</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>A presentation deck by a researcher from a Russian institute on compiler obfuscation</li>
<li>An installer and multiple other files pertaining to an EDR product, likely used once again for testing the AV/EDR bypass tool</li>
<li>A text file with escrow payment details (shown in Figure 11)</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<figure id="attachment_137235" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137235" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137235 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-393073-137213-11.png" alt="Screenshot that includes the file name 'data.txt' with partially obscured text." width="600" height="130" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137235" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Text file with payment information.</figcaption></figure>
<ul>
<li>Another text file containing a long list of host IP addresses along with their credentials
<ul>
<li>A portion of those credentials likely corresponds to various compromised hosts.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Р-1 form expense spreadsheet</li>
</ul>
<p>One file from the rogue system that caught our attention was <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Р-1 (акт выполненных работ) № &lt;redacted&gt; от &lt;redacted&gt;.xls</span>, which translates to “act of completed work.” The spreadsheet contains a “P-1 form” for a transaction between two limited liability companies based in Kazakhstan, as shown in Figure 12.</p>
<p>According to <a href="https://goszakup.gov.kz/ru/news/view/146" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a post on the government procurement site for the Republic of Kazakhstan</a>, the P-1 form is used to document completed work, services rendered, invoices (as in this case), and other related items. The name of one of the companies exposed in this document reveals a piece of information that is vital when it comes to threat actor profiling.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137237" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137237" style="width: 1600px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137237 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-395573-137213-12.png" alt="Screenshot of an Excel spreadsheet with multiple rows and columns containing data, with specific areas redacted for privacy. A red arrow points to a cell in which a Kazakhstan-based LLC was mentioned. The spreadsheet includes headers, numeric data, and text descriptions in Russian." width="1600" height="1150" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-395573-137213-12.png 1600w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-395573-137213-12-612x440.png 612w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-395573-137213-12-974x700.png 974w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-395573-137213-12-768x552.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-395573-137213-12-1536x1104.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1600px) 100vw, 1600px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137237" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. P-1 form recovered from the rogue system.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-137213-_z8s349is3h4v"></a><strong>Artifacts from AV/EDR Bypass Tool Recording</strong></h3>
<p>We previously mentioned the presence of multiple video files demonstrating the AV/EDR bypass tool against various endpoint protection products. These files are identical to the ones provided by a user account named <em>KernelMode</em> on various cybercrime forums.</p>
<p>We found the video recording shown in Figure 13, and noted a few relevant details on an AV/EDR agent panel and the taskbar of the host machine.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137239" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137239" style="width: 2048px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137239 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-399658-137213-13.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer desktop with multiple open windows, including a command prompt and file explorer. There is also a screenshot of an interface with sections such as Agent Details (selected), Threat History, Overview and more. The desktop background features a diagram with lines and nodes." width="2048" height="1268" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-399658-137213-13.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-399658-137213-13-711x440.png 711w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-399658-137213-13-1131x700.png 1131w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-399658-137213-13-768x476.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-399658-137213-13-1536x951.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137239" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Screenshot of an AV/EDR bypass tool video demonstration.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Our observations based on the video noted in Figure 13 include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The AV/EDR bypass tool is being tested in a virtual machine and is accessible via Oracle VM VirtualBox. Looking at the taskbar of the host machine (as shown at the bottom of Figure 13 above), it appears that the individual recording the demonstration video is accessing multiple instances of virtual machines.</li>
<li>The virtual machine hostname displayed on the AV/EDR agent panel is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DESKTOP-J8AOTJS</span>. This also happens to be the hostname of the rogue system behind the attack that we managed to capture. With this piece of information, we can confirm that the rogue system is a virtual machine.</li>
<li>The management console URL on the agent panel seems rather unconventional: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">https[://]temp.vxsh[.]net</span>. A quick search on this domain reveals a Telegram channel where a user shared a fake token to install the AV/EDR agent. Base64-decoding of the fake token unveils that exact URL. We cannot confirm if the agent can still be installed via this particular fake token.</li>
<li>Looking at the titles of open applications in the Windows taskbar in the host machine, the first one from the right, beside the Google Chrome icon, is incomplete but appears to have a name in it showing as “Andr.”</li>
<li>While going through the remaining videos, we identified the same application in the taskbar but this time, the first word “Andry” is visible in the title “Andry-ad…” as shown below in Figure 14. The icon indicates this application is likely <a href="https://wiki.mikrotik.com/wiki/Manual:Winbox" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WinBox</a>, a utility used to remotely log into and administer Mikrotik routers. We believe that “Andry” is part of the username logged into a Mikrotik router.</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_137241" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137241" style="width: 544px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137241 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-404239-137213-14.png" alt="Logos of four applications: including Chrome and OBS Studio displayed in a taskbar. " width="544" height="72" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137241" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Snippet of Windows taskbar from one of the demonstration videos.</figcaption></figure>
<p><em>Figure 14. Snippet of Windows taskbar from one of the demonstration videos.</em></p>
<ul>
<li>As shown above in Figure 14, another application visible in the taskbar is <a href="https://obsproject.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">OBS Studio</a>, a free and open-source tool for video recording and live streaming. Threat actors often abuse, take advantage of or subvert legitimate products for malicious purposes. This does not imply that the legitimate product is flawed or malicious.</li>
</ul>
<h3></h3>
<h3><a id="post-137213-_7xck2nieam9x"></a><strong>Browser History</strong></h3>
<p>Through Cortex XDR we got a peek into Edge browser activity on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DESKTOP-J8AOTJS</span> as shown below in Figure 15. We observed the adversary's operations included visiting the following websites to search for and download certain tools such as <a href="https://processhacker.sourceforge.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Process Hacker</a> and <a href="https://doublecmd.sourceforge.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Double Commander</a>.</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ya[.]ru</span>: Yandex (Russian-based search engine)</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sourceforge[.]net</span></li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_137243" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137243" style="width: 2048px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137243 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-406503-137213-15.png" alt="Screenshot of a webpage displaying a history for Edge Anaheim with various entries. The page layout includes columns for title and URL. The screen displays a total of 26 found results." width="2048" height="1452" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-406503-137213-15.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-406503-137213-15-621x440.png 621w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-406503-137213-15-987x700.png 987w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-406503-137213-15-768x545.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-406503-137213-15-1536x1089.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137243" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. Portion of the adversary’s browser history.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-137213-_q85ueiyhn96o"></a>Additional Findings</h2>
<h3><a id="post-137213-_yh9lwz47e3eo"></a><strong>TTP Overlaps with Conti Playbook</strong></h3>
<p>As noted in the previous section, the rogue system contained <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ContiTraining.rar</span>, but we found no indication that the attackers downloaded material from the Conti playbook on the rogue system. However, we observed some overlaps between the Conti playbook and tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) captured during this incident attack chain, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Use of Atera agent to access the client network and maintain persistence</li>
<li>Cobalt Strike beaconing activity</li>
<li>Use of PsExec for lateral movement</li>
<li>Data exfiltration using Rclone utility</li>
</ul>
<h3></h3>
<h3><a id="post-137213-_fjkc2743g2d2"></a><strong>Findings from Cobalt Strike Watermark</strong></h3>
<p>We extracted configuration data from Cobalt Strike beacons used during the attack, and the watermark ID across all the extracted configuration data was <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1357776117</span>. <a href="https://threatfox-api.abuse.ch/browse/tag/cs-watermark-1357776117/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Threatfox</a> has so far identified around 160 unique IPv4 and domain names associated with this particular Cobalt Strike watermark ID.</p>
<p>Cobalt Strike activity has frequently been noted in ransomware attacks, and a small portion of the identified Cobalt Strike IPv4 and domain names have also been associated with Dark Scorpius (aka Black Basta) ransomware. Despite the association of Cobalt Strike with ransomware, we did not observe any attempts to deploy ransomware during our investigation. We speculate this might be because the threat actor lost access to the network before attempting further actions.</p>
<h2></h2>
<h2><a id="post-137213-_m5ixlg3m4x8y"></a>Threat Actor Profiling</h2>
<p>Files on the rogue system, like the AV/EDR bypass tool demonstration videos and the P-1 form, constitute an operational security (OpSec) failure by the threat actor that exposed information we believe helps us identify them.</p>
<p>We identified the LinkedIn profile of the individual whose name (“Andry”) we captured from the video. The individual is employed at the company based in Kazakhstan listed in the P-1 form. Furthermore, we found a matching profile on the Russian social networking platform VKontakte, which reveals more details about the individual.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137245" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137245" style="width: 540px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137245 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-410046-137213-16.png" alt="Screenshot of a LinkedIn profile page with minimal content: profile photo placeholder, no connections, and placeholder text for activity and experience sections." width="540" height="742" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-410046-137213-16.png 540w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-410046-137213-16-320x440.png 320w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-410046-137213-16-509x700.png 509w" sizes="(max-width: 540px) 100vw, 540px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137245" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. Linkedin profile of the rogue individual.</figcaption></figure>
<p>We also gathered additional details on the organization employing this individual, including its website, legal address and registration details. According to its website, the company currently has five employees, including the individual in question. The website also provides a personal and professional description for each of its employees, providing further insight on the individual we believe to be involved in this attack.</p>
<h3><a id="post-137213-_63a6zgjjb6ml"></a><strong>KernelMode Connection</strong></h3>
<p>Revisiting some of the points we covered so far:</p>
<ul>
<li>The rogue system <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DESKTOP-J8AOTJS</span> contained multiple recordings of an AV/EDR bypass tool being demonstrated against various EDR products</li>
<li>Those exact videos were also distributed by an actor that uses the moniker <em>KernelMode </em>on different cybercrime forums</li>
<li>The Windows taskbar exposed the name of the host machine in those recordings</li>
<li>Additionally, a P-1 expense form was present on the rogue system, revealing the name of the company employing the individual</li>
<li>We pivoted on this information to discover what we believe to be the true identity of the individual, along with personal and professional details</li>
</ul>
<p>With these points in mind, we assess with moderate confidence that the individual in question is one of the people, if not the only person, behind <em>KernelMode</em>. Moreover, based on the individual’s background and relevant information we gathered, this individual is likely one of the developers, if not the only developer, of the AV/EDR bypass tool.</p>
<p>However, we cannot ascertain if this particular individual is the owner of the rogue virtual machine <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DESKTOP-J8AOTJS</span>, and by extension, the person behind this whole attack. This is primarily due to the following reasons:</p>
<ul>
<li>The rogue individual is definitely one of the active users of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DESKTOP-J8AOTJS</span>, but access to this virtual machine could have been shared across multiple individuals. There isn’t concrete evidence to suggest otherwise.</li>
<li>There is no indication of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DESKTOP-J8AOTJS</span> being involved in the attack, except for the purposes of AV/EDR bypass.</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-137213-_sx18kp9uxdij"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Recently, there has been a growing trend in the use of AV/EDR bypass tools, extending beyond the incident discussed here. These tools will likely continue to evolve in their attempts to exploit various security platforms.</p>
<p>Ongoing monitoring of underground forums provides valuable insights into the latest developments and techniques of these tools. Threat actors and developers monetize such platforms on a subscription basis, regularly releasing updates as part of their affiliate payment plans.</p>
<p>This incident allowed us to expose a rogue system and, by extension, the toolkit and files owned by the threat actor. Using all the information gathered, Unit 42 unveiled what we believe to be the true identity of one of the threat actors and assessed their involvement in this incident.</p>
<p>Organizations should consider blocking the indicators of compromise provided in this report, as they are associated with the arsenal observed in the incident, as well as the toolkit present in the rogue system. More broadly, we recommend reviewing your security tool policies and configurations to ensure that agent tampering protection is enabled, preventing malicious activities targeting the endpoint protection agents on your systems.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137213-_lsbythhc3nz9"></a>Palo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation</h2>
<p>For Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this group:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire?_gl=1*nq7ug8*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTcyNDAwMC4zMC4xLjE2Njk3MjQwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> cloud-delivered malware analysis service accurately identifies the known samples as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/dns-security?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> identify known URLs and domains associated with this activity as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsiam" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> detect and prevent all samples mentioned in this article.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the<a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137213-_mcojh0xfl9eo"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>

<h2><a id="post-137213-_lc50h0v3p9or"></a>Appendix</h2>
<h3><a id="post-137213-_y6jle3f62fm5"></a>Incident Attack Lifecycle</h3>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th><strong>MITRE Tactic</strong></th>
<th><strong>Description</strong></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>Initial access (TA0001)</th>
<th>Access to the client network via Atera RMM purchased from an initial access broker.</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>Persistence (TA0003)</th>
<th>Creation of scheduled tasks to routinely execute Cobalt Strike beacons.</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>Defense Evasion (TA0005)</th>
<th>AV/EDR bypass tool called <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">disabler.exe</span>. It uses the static library from <a href="https://github.com/wavestone-cdt/EDRSandblast" target="_blank" rel="noopener">EDRSandBlast</a>, a hack tool designed to unhook EDR hooks in both user-mode libraries and kernel-mode.</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>Credential Access (TA0006)</th>
<th>The threat actor leveraged Mimikatz and executed PowerShell to obtain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">lsass.exe</span> process dump.</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>Discovery (TA0007)</th>
<th>A series of internal discovery commands on a compromised domain controller using built-in tools such as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">nltest, net, dsquery</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">rundll32</span>.</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>Lateral Movement (TA0008)</th>
<th>The threat actor used Windows RDP and PsExec to move laterally between systems in the victim environment.</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>Exfiltration (TA0010)</th>
<th>Attackers used Rclone to exfiltrate data from the victim environment to a Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) server.</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>Command and Control (TA0011)</th>
<th>Cobalt Strike Beacon activity on multiple systems.</th>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 1 November, 2024 at 3:37 PM PDT</span>-->

                    <h4 class="post-title">Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/red-teaming-tool/" title="red teaming tool" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="edr-bypass-extortion-attempt-thwarted:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:red teaming tool">Red teaming tool</a>

					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/pentest-tool/" title="pentest tool" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="edr-bypass-extortion-attempt-thwarted:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:pentest tool">Pentest tool</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/analysis-pentest-tool-splinter/" title="Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="edr-bypass-extortion-attempt-thwarted:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/word-image-449925-135181-16-786x368.png" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of APT groups from North Korea. Abstract, stylized cosmic setting with vibrant blue and purple shapes, representing space and distant planetary bodies." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/word-image-449925-135181-16-786x368.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/word-image-449925-135181-16-1493x700.png 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/word-image-449925-135181-16-768x360.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/word-image-449925-135181-16-1536x720.png 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/word-image-449925-135181-16.png 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="edr-bypass-extortion-attempt-thwarted:related-resources:Gleaming Pisces Poisoned Python Packages Campaign Delivers PondRAT Linux and MacOS Backdoors:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-09-18T21:00:59+00:00">September 18, 2024</time></span>

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			                 <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:400px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			                  <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:949px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
